{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17579,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron indicum, also known as the Indica Azalea, thrives in moist but well-drained soil. It is important to water the plant regularly, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. The soil should remain consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet soil can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the fall and winter months, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant's growth slows down. Always use rainwater or distilled water if possible, because Rhododendrons are sensitive to high levels of lime found in tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron indicum requires a balance of sunlight and shade to flourish. It prefers bright, indirect sunlight or partial shade, making it ideal for gardens that receive morning sun with afternoon shade. Excessive direct sunlight, especially in hotter climates, can scorch the leaves and dry the plant out. In contrast, too little light may result in poor blooming. When planting outdoors, position your Rhododendron in an area that is sheltered from harsh afternoon sunlight and strong winds. Indoors, place the potted plant near a window that receives filtered light, avoiding direct afternoon rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning your Rhododendron indicum helps maintain its shape and encourages abundant flowering. The best time to prune is right after the plant has finished blooming in the late spring or early summer. You can gently remove dead flowers, known as deadheading, to promote new blooms and keep the plant tidy. Cut back any weak or straggly branches to encourage bushier growth. It's also a good time to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as it may reduce next year’s blooms. Always use clean, sharp tools to minimize stress and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tsutsusi azalea","description":"Rhododendron indicum is an Azalea Rhododendron species native to Japan (S & W Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu, Yakushima). It is the type species for the Tsutsusi section and subsection, and was the original Tsutsusi described by Engelbert Kaempfer in Japan in 1712, from the Japanese name Kirishima-tsutsuji.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Japan","China"],"other_name":["tsutsusi azalea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids","Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Layering Propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Rhododendron indicum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17080,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tilia platyphyllos, commonly known as Large-leaved Linden, prefers consistently moist soil, especially when newly planted or during periods of drought. Water the tree deeply once a week in the absence of sufficient rainfall, ensuring that the soil remains evenly moist but not waterlogged. Once established, the tree is moderately drought-tolerant but will still benefit from regular watering in prolonged dry spells. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure good drainage. Monitor the soil moisture regularly, adjusting the frequency of watering based on weather conditions and evaporation rates."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tilia platyphyllos thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its robust growth and flowering potential. In areas with hot summers, it can benefit from some afternoon shade to protect it from excessive heat stress. However, too much shade can result in sparser foliage and reduced flowering. When choosing a planting location, ensure it's in a position that provides ample sunlight exposure while considering nearby buildings or trees that may cast shadows. Proper sunlight will encourage healthy growth and a well-shaped canopy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tilia platyphyllos is best done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, diseased, or crossing branches to maintain a healthy structure. Thinning out crowded branches can improve air circulation, reducing the risk of disease. Additionally, remove any suckers or water sprouts that may appear at the base or on the trunk to ensure nutrients are directed towards the main growth. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the tree and inhibit its natural shape. Keeping up with regular maintenance will promote a strong structure and prevent potential damage during storms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bigleaf Linden","description":"Tilia platyphyllos is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae (Tiliaceae). It is a deciduous tree, native to much of Europe, including locally in southwestern Great Britain, growing on lime-rich soils. The common names largeleaf linden and large-leaved linden are in standard use throughout the English-speaking world except in the British Isles, where it is widely, but not universally, known as large-leaved lime. The name \"lime\", possibly a corruption of \"line\" originally from \"lind\",...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Southwest Asia"],"other_name":["Bigleaf Linden"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Tilia platyphyllos"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is more drought-tolerant once established, so it's better to err on the side of underwatering than overwatering. Reduce the frequency of watering during the winter months, as the plant's growth slows and it requires less moisture. Ensure the pot or garden soil has good drainage to prevent water from sitting around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia cotinifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a location where it can receive at least six hours of sunlight each day, which helps maintain its vibrant reddish-purple foliage. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch, but too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced color intensity. Positioning near a south or west-facing window indoors can provide adequate light if the plant is grown as a houseplant. Ensure it is gradually acclimated to more intense sunlight to prevent leaf damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia cotinifolia helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Prune in early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, clean shears to cut back any dead or damaged branches, trimming just above a leaf node. This plant can become leggy, so regular pruning encourages bushier growth. Be sure to wear gloves when pruning, as the plant's latex can be irritating to the skin. If a fuller shape is desired, pinch back the tips of the branches to promote branching."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican shrubby spurge","description":"Euphorbia cotinifolia is a broadleaf red shrub native to Mexico and South America. Treated as a shrub, it reaches 10 to 15 ft (3.0 to 4.6 m) but can be grown as a tree reaching 30 ft (9.1 m). Small white flowers with creamy bracts bloom at the ends of the branches in summer. The purplish stems, when broken, exude a sap that is a skin irritant.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Red to purplish-brown"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Mexican shrubby spurge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia cotinifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16975,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sclerocactus scheeri is a drought-tolerant cactus that thrives in arid environments. When watering, it's essential to let the soil dry out completely between waterings to avoid root rot. During its active growing season, typically in spring and early summer, water the cactus thoroughly but infrequently. Reduce watering in the fall and cease altogether during winter dormancy. Ensure the pot has drainage holes and uses a well-draining cactus mix to help prevent standing water around the roots. Overwatering is the most common cause of problems with this species, so err on the side of caution."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sclerocactus scheeri requires plenty of bright sunlight to thrive, mimicking its natural desert habitat. Ideally, place it in an area where it can receive a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight each day. A south or west-facing window is usually suitable. If natural light is insufficient, particularly in winter months, consider supplementing with grow lights to maintain its health. Be cautious of intense light and heat through windows, which can scorch the plant. Gradually introduce the cactus to full sun to prevent sunburn if moving it from a shaded area."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sclerocactus scheeri is not commonly required, as it's a slow-growing cactus with minimal foliage. However, removing any dead or decaying parts can promote better overall health. Water thoroughly until it runs out of the drainage hole, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season (spring and summer), you might need to water once a week, but reduce this frequency in the dormant months (fall and winter) to once a month or even less. Be careful not to let water sit in the rosettes to avoid rot, and ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent overwatering problems."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echeveria simulans thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It is best to place this plant near a south or east-facing window where it can receive at least 4 to 6 hours of bright light daily. Inadequate sunlight can cause the plant to become leggy and lose its vibrant leaf colors. If natural light is insufficient, consider supplementing with grow lights. However, too much direct midday sun, especially in hot climates, can cause leaf burn, so it's wise to provide some shade during the hottest parts of the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Echeveria simulans requires minimal pruning. Regular removal of dead or dying leaves at the base helps prevent pest and disease problems. Simply pull away these old leaves or use a pair of sharp, sterile scissors. If the plant becomes leggy, you can cut the rosette off with a stem and allow it to callous over for a few days before replanting to start a new plant. Avoid pruning healthy leaves frequently as this type of succulent does not require shaping or excessive maintenance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Leaf","Offsets"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Echeveria simulans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. During the summer months or in warmer climates, you might need to water more frequently, while in winter or cooler environments, reduce the watering frequency accordingly. Be sure to use well-draining soil to help excess water escape, ensuring the roots are not sitting in water, which could cause damage to this delicate plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Australina pusilla thrives in partial to full shade conditions, making it an ideal plant for spots that do not receive direct sunlight. It can handle dappled sunlight under trees, but prolonged exposure to direct sun can cause the leaves to scorch or dry out. Aim to place the plant in a north or east-facing location if indoors, or under a canopy or shaded area if outdoors. While it adapts well to low light, insufficient light can result in slower growth, so ensure the plant receives some indirect light daily."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Australina pusilla is generally minimal as it maintains a manageable size and shape throughout its growth. However, occasional pruning may be beneficial to remove dead or damaged leaves, encouraging healthier growth and maintaining a tidy appearance. It's best to prune in the early spring before the new growth starts, using clean, sharp scissors to avoid damaging the plant. Regular deadheading—the removal of spent flowers—can also promote further blooming and prevent the plant from becoming too unruly or leggy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Small Shade Nettle","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Small Shade Nettle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Australina pusilla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Typically, it is best to water the plant deeply once every week or so during dry spells. Ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged conditions, as this can lead to root rot. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings. In general, Penstemon hirsutus prefers well-drained soil and can survive with minimal supplemental watering once established, especially during cooler seasons."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Penstemon hirsutus thrives best in full sun conditions, meaning it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, it can tolerate partial shade, especially in extremely hot climates, though flowering might be reduced. Providing ample sunlight helps the plant develop its characteristic vibrant blooms and maintain its health. If planted in shadier spots, ensure it receives some afternoon sun to optimize growth and bloom potential, but in very harsh sunlight, some light afternoon shade can be beneficial."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Penstemon hirsutus involves removing dead or damaged stems and spent flowers, usually in the late fall or early spring. This helps promote vigorous growth and flowering in the next growing season. Cut back the stems to just above the basal foliage if the plant looks untidy or to encourage more compact growth. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease spread. Pruning also encourages more blooms and can help in managing the shape and size of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"hairy beardtongue","description":"Penstemon hirsutus is a species of flowering plant in the plantain family known by the common name hairy beard-tongue.
